src: ɛlɛ     ndana  ɛ-g-ɛ    na    nɛ   a Kʷɔʃɛwa
trs: [When] this thing happened, I was [living] at Kossewa.’\\
I was sleeping.
Some time later, the snake went.

imt: \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s}-climb at house   wood      in {\textsc{id}:sound of snake}
src: à-tsar  a  haj  kɪrɛ  ava  {fɔ fɔ fɔ}
trs: It climbed into the beams in the roof of the house \textit{fo fo fo}.

src: nɛ awij    alma   amə-dəv=ala ɔkʷfɔm   nɛhɛ    maj
trs: [I woke up]  I said [to myself], “What made that mouse fall?”
Then, I turned on a light,
I took my flashlight.

src: nɛ awij    a          ɛnɛŋ       baj     na  mɛmɛj   na
trs: I said to myself, “Wah! It’s a snake!”’ (lit. a snake, if not, how)
It penetrated, \textit{mbəraɓ}!

src: ɛlɛ     a        Hʊrmbʊlɔm  ɛlɛ     ga      à-dzən=aw    ɛtɛ
trs: God helped me also’\\
I clubbed it to death (approximately).
My wife went and said,’\\

src: bijna      à-nzak-aj          nɔkʷ   ha      a    ɬam      mɪ-nd-ijɛ=aŋgʷɔ  ava
trs: Because it found you even in your bed.’ (lit. all the way to the place of your lying)\\
And then God helped you; thanks [be to] God!”

src: a-l=ala    n\`ə-ɮərav         na=ala  gʷɔgʷɔlvaŋ  na  a  amata  ava
trs: Sometime later I took the snake outside.

src: kʷɔ     dɛdɛw     babəza=uwla=ahaj  amə-ɮərav=ala  amata      na    tawij
trs: Early the next morning, when my children came outside, they said,’\\

src: baba     á-kaɗ gʷɔgʷɔlvaŋ  baba   á-kaɗ gʷɔgʷɔlvaŋ
trs: “Papa killed a snake, Papa killed a snake!”

src: ka  nɛhɛ  ləbara  a       ma      ndana  ɗuwgɛ
trs: And so was that story.
Once upon a time…’ (lit. there’s a story under the silo)

imt: \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{p}+said  saying   word   story   {\GEN}   child   female  disobedience   {\ADJ}
src: tawij  abija    ma   bamba   a       war     dalaj      tʃɛɮɛrɛ        ga
trs: They say, the story of the disobedient girl [goes like this:]’\\

imt: {\DEP}-grind={\PLU}  on   stone   on    {\PSP}  \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s}+{\IFV}-grind  child   eye   millet    one
src: amə-h=aja   kə   vɛr   aka  na  tá-zaɗ       war   ɛlɛ  haj  bɪlɛŋ
trs: For grinding on the grinding stone, they would take one grain of millet.’\\

src: ndɛ  asa t\'ə-ndaj    tá-h=aja      na  na
trs: So, whenever they were grinding it,’\\
the flour, it multiplied with multiplying.’ \\

src: war     ɛlɛ   haj   bɪlɛŋ   faŋ   na
trs: Just one grain of millet,’\\
it sufficed for them, even to leaving leftovers.’ (lit. until it remained again)\\
Because, during its grinding,’\\

src: aɮəna  war   dalaj   ndana tʃɛɮɛrɛ          ga
trs: Now, that young girl was disobedient.’\\
Then her husband’\\
If you want to grind’ (lit. if grinding pleases you),\\
you take only one grain.’\\

src: war    ɛlɛ      haj     bɪlɛŋ  ga   nɪndijɛ  nɔkʷ amɛ-ʒɪɗ-ɛ na
trs: That one grain that you have taken,’\\
It will suffice for all of us just enough.’ \\
because, during the grinding,’\\
God is multiplying it for us.”’\\
The woman replied,’\\
saying, “Yes, my dear husband.”
She, sleeping there for some time, her husband went away’\\

src: amɛ-tɛl-ɛ     kə  dɪlmɛtɛ=ahaŋ      aka   a  ɬam  ɛnɛŋ
trs: to walk~in the neighborhood to some place.’ \\
Once upon a time…’ (lit. story, story)
[As] they were walking in the bush,’\\

src: náá{}-mənzar   na=alaj   mɛmɛlɛ ga   ndana  uwɗɛ
trs: First I want to see the tree that you spoke of.”

src: ndɛ  mɪʒɛ=ahaj  gʷɔgʷɔr=ahaj ga  na   ŋgama
trs: So, our elders [have it] better.
